title: Restoring Accountability to Policy-Influencing Positions Within the Federal Workforce

enrichment.summary: This executive order reinstates and updates a prior policy that creates a special excepted service classification for federal employees in policy-influencing positions, making it easier to hold them accountable and remove those who do not implement the President's policies faithfully. It aims to restore presidential control and accountability over career federal employees who shape and influence government policy, reversing protections that have made it difficult for supervisors to discipline or remove underperforming or insubordinate employees.
potential_concerns: The policy could undermine long-standing civil service protections that safeguard employee rights and merit-based employment, risking politicization of the federal workforce.
Making removal easier for policy-influencing career employees may discourage qualified candidates from seeking these positions due to job insecurity and political pressures.
There may be challenges in clearly defining which positions qualify for the new Schedule Policy/Career classification, leading to inconsistent or arbitrary application across agencies.
The order risks creating tension and reduced morale among federal employees who feel their oaths or professional responsibilities conflict with implementing policies they disagree with.
Revoking protections and previous reform efforts might face legal challenges and impede implementation, resulting in temporary uncertainty and administrative burden.
